awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Broadening Participation in Computing through Transforming Media and Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates computational projects where participating members transform media by producing new creative works that draw material and inspiration from another source - often in order to critique and correct the exclusion of certain types of characters or narratives from the underlying media and to amplify underrepresented voices. Computational projects expand this practice into the transformation of technologies, which subsequently provides a path for broadening participation in computing, since these communities have a large percentage of participation from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in computing, such as women and people with disabilities. Broadening participation is essential for ensuring that a diversity of perspectives are involved in creating new technologies, and despite initiatives aimed at bringing more diverse groups into computer science, certain groups are still under-involved in formal computing spaces such as education programs and the broader technology industry. In contrast to work that seeks to bring underrepresented groups into these formal spaces, this research will examine computational work already happening within communities that both experience marginalization and where participants who may be outsiders to traditional computing culture are engaging with computation in order to empower their own communities. By studying this work, this research can lead to a better understanding of how to overcome systemic barriers that marginalized and underrepresented groups face when entering formal computing spaces.
 
The research will take place across multiple case studies of computational projects, in order to explore how they innovate and transform technologies, with an emphasis on their involvement in projects by and for marginalized communities. These case studies will involve interviews, participant observation, and ethnography around the ongoing creation of new content and platforms, including those that address privacy, safety, accessibility, and other concerns specific to marginalized groups that are overlooked on other platforms. This work stands to inform perspectives on barriers to broadening participation in computing and how computing can empower marginalized communities. The result will be a better understanding of how those who are traditionally crowded out of computing are motivated to get involved in computational projects - and how we might encourage and support them. This research will provide insight into not only how computational projects driven by underrepresented groups function and what their benefits are to marginalized communities, but also what motivating factors make this kind of work possible when efforts to broaden participation in computing often fall short.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to broadly study computational projects in transformative fandom communities as a pathway towards computing, particularly for women, with video game modding and creation and maintenance of online social platforms as specific case studies. In contrast to work that seeks to bring underrepresented groups into formal computing spaces, this research examined computational work already happening within communities that both experience marginalization and where participants who may be outsiders to traditional computing culture are engaging with computation in order to empower their own communities. 

The research conducted as part of this project included: (1) multiple interview studies with members of fandom communities, the vast majority of whom identified as part of populations traditionally underrepresented in computing; (2) a large-scale survey based on the results of those interviews; and (3) digital ethnography of design documentation, polices, and user interactions on a fan-created social platform. A major finding related to broadening participation in computing was the strength of stereotypes about what ?counts? as computer science and what computational labor looks like; many of our participants undermined their own competence in computer science because they felt they did not meet some imagined standard of what that competence should look like. However, they were still performing complex computational tasks ?for fun? and learning skills that many later applied to technical careers--while contrasting those experiences to formal computer science education spaces, that our participants by and large described as boring or frustrating. Our findings also pointed to ways that members of marginalized communities use technology to empower themselves and their communities, and opportunities for scaffolding informal learning in these environments. Finally, findings focused on fan game developers point to curricular opportunities that harness themes of playfulness and collaboration to build relationships, empower students, and combat stereotypes.

This work has been disseminated to multiple scholarly communities with publications and conference presentations in both computer science education and collaborative computing venues. It has also been shared more broadly through blog posts aimed at a scholarly and educator audience as well as social media (e.g., Tumblr and TikTok) aimed at the general public and our fandom participant population. The graduate student researcher who led this project is also now computer science faculty herself, and describes her ultimate career goal as ?to empower learners across all ranges of computer science to truly take ownership of the discipline.? The outcomes of this research project have pointed to best practices to help computing instructors at all levels realize this goal as well.
